title: 2 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 9.

questions.question: Who did Elisha send to anoint Jehu as king over Israel?
options: One of the children of the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: One of the children of the prophets
questions.explanation: Elisha called one of the children of the prophets to anoint Jehu king (2 Kings 9:1).

questions.question: Where was Jehu anointed king according to the chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Ramothgilead
questions.explanation: The young man went to Ramothgilead and anointed Jehu king there (2 Kings 9:4-6).

questions.question: What was poured on Jehu's head to anoint him king?
questions.correctAnswer: Oil
questions.explanation: The prophet poured a box of oil on Jehu's head to anoint him king (2 Kings 9:3, 6).

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 9:7, whose house was Jehu commanded to smite?
questions.correctAnswer: The house of Ahab
questions.explanation: Jehu was instructed to smite the house of Ahab to avenge the blood of the prophets and servants of the LORD (2 Kings 9:7).

questions.question: What was to happen to Jezebel according to the prophecy given to Jehu?
options: Dogs shall eat her in Jezreel
She would be buried with honor
questions.correctAnswer: Dogs shall eat her in Jezreel
questions.explanation: It was prophesied that dogs would eat Jezebel in the portion of Jezreel and none would bury her (2 Kings 9:10).

questions.question: Who came down to Jezreel to see King Joram?
questions.correctAnswer: Ahaziah king of Judah
questions.explanation: Ahaziah king of Judah came down to Jezreel to see Joram (2 Kings 9:16).

questions.question: How did Jehu respond when asked if there was peace by the king's messengers?
options: What hast thou to do with peace? turn thee behind me
questions.correctAnswer: What hast thou to do with peace? turn thee behind me
questions.explanation: Jehu told the messengers to turn behind him and questioned what they had to do with peace (2 Kings 9:18, 19).

questions.question: Where did Jehu meet Joram and Ahaziah in battle?
options: The portion of Naboth the Jezreelite
questions.correctAnswer: The portion of Naboth the Jezreelite
questions.explanation: Jehu met Joram and Ahaziah at the portion of Naboth the Jezreelite (2 Kings 9:21).

questions.question: True or False: Jehu killed Joram with an arrow between his arms.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jehu drew a bow and smote Joram between his arms, killing him (2 Kings 9:24).

questions.question: What did Jehu command his captain Bidkar to do with Joram's body?
options: Cast him into the portion of Naboth
questions.correctAnswer: Cast him into the portion of Naboth
questions.explanation: Jehu ordered Bidkar to cast Joram's body into the portion of Naboth in accordance with the LORD's word (2 Kings 9:25-26).

questions.question: What happened to Ahaziah king of Judah after fleeing Jezreel?
options: He was struck down and died at Megiddo
He hid in a garden house
questions.correctAnswer: He was struck down and died at Megiddo
questions.explanation: Ahaziah fled but was smitten by Jehu and died at Megiddo (2 Kings 9:27).

questions.question: True or False: Jezebel welcomed Jehu when he entered Jezreel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jezebel mocked Jehu from a window, not welcoming him (2 Kings 9:30-31).

questions.question: What was Jezebel's fate as described when she was thrown down from the window?
options: Some of her blood was sprinkled on the wall and horses, and she was trodden underfoot
She escaped and hid in the city
questions.correctAnswer: Some of her blood was sprinkled on the wall and horses, and she was trodden underfoot
questions.explanation: When Jezebel was thrown down, some of her blood splattered on the wall and horses, and Jehu trod her underfoot (2 Kings 9:33).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 2 Kings 9:36, the word of the LORD spoken by Elijah said, 'In the portion of Jezreel shall ____ eat the flesh of Jezebel.'
questions.correctAnswer: dogs
questions.explanation: Elijah prophesied that dogs would eat Jezebel's flesh in Jezreel (2 Kings 9:36).

questions.question: True or False: Jehu ate and drank after entering Jezreel and then told others to bury Jezebel.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jehu ate and drank and then instructed others to bury Jezebel because she was a king's daughter (2 Kings 9:34).

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 9 teach us about obedience to God's instructions when faced with a difficult task?
options: Wait for others to act first
Modify the instructions to suit your comfort
Ignore instructions if they seem hard
questions.correctAnswer: Obey promptly and without hesitation
questions.explanation: The young prophet obeyed Elisha's command to anoint Jehu and then fled immediately without delay (2 Kings 9:3, 9:4, 9:10). This shows the importance of prompt obedience to God's Word.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with trusting God's promises in leadership. Based on Jehu's anointing, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God appoints leaders for His purposes
Leaders arise through human effort alone
Leadership is based only on popularity
God does not involve Himself in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: God appoints leaders for His purposes
questions.explanation: God explicitly anointed Jehu king over Israel through the prophet, showing divine appointment for specific purposes (2 Kings 9:6-7, 9:13, 9:14).

questions.question: How does Jehu's swift action against Joram and Ahaziah demonstrate integrity in fulfilling God's justice?
options: He acted decisively to fulfill God's command
He delayed to gather more support
He sought revenge for personal reasons
questions.correctAnswer: He acted decisively to fulfill God's command
questions.explanation: Jehu immediately rode to Jezreel to confront Joram and Ahaziah, fulfilling God's judgment without delay (2 Kings 9:16-24, 9:27).

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 9 teach about perseverance through trials, especially when facing opposition?
questions.correctAnswer: Continue faithfully despite opposition
questions.explanation: Jehu faced opposition from kings and servants but persisted in carrying out God's will (2 Kings 9:20-24, 9:33-36). This models perseverance through trials.

questions.question: How does Jehu's respect for God's word about Naboth's blood illustrate stewardship of God's justice?
options: He ensured God's justice was fulfilled exactly
He ignored God's commands for convenience
He sought personal gain from the situation
questions.correctAnswer: He ensured God's justice was fulfilled exactly
questions.explanation: Jehu instructed that Joram's body be cast into Naboth's field as God had commanded, showing faithfulness to God's justice (2 Kings 9:25-26).

questions.question: When Jezebel tried to intimidate Jehu, what can we learn about humility and contentment in God's protection?
options: Trust in God's protection rather than fear enemies
Rely on your own strength to fight
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's protection rather than fear enemies
questions.explanation: Jehu confronted Jezebel boldly, trusting God's authority rather than fearing her threats (2 Kings 9:30-33, 9:36-37).

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing temptation to compromise their faith for social acceptance. Based on Jehu's example, what would you advise?
options: Remain steadfast and carry out God's will
Blend in with the crowd to avoid conflict
Ignore God's commands to fit in
questions.correctAnswer: Remain steadfast and carry out God's will
questions.explanation: Jehu boldly fulfilled God's commands despite opposition and the influence of Jezebel’s house (2 Kings 9:7, 9:22-24).

questions.question: How does the public declaration of Jehu as king teach about the importance of communal affirmation in church life?
options: Public acknowledgment unites and affirms leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Public acknowledgment unites and affirms leadership
questions.explanation: The captains and servants publicly declared Jehu king by putting garments and blowing trumpets, showing the importance of communal affirmation (2 Kings 9:12-13).

questions.question: How does Jehu's immediate obedience to God's command relate to spiritual discipline in daily life?
questions.correctAnswer: Prompt obedience strengthens spiritual discipline
questions.explanation: Jehu's quick response to the prophet's anointing and subsequent actions highlight the value of prompt, disciplined obedience (2 Kings 9:3-4, 9:11-12).

questions.question: True or False: Jehu ignored the prophetic word about Jezebel and treated her with kindness when he arrived at Jezreel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jehu fulfilled the prophecy about Jezebel by having her thrown down and trampled, fulfilling Elijah’s word (2 Kings 9:33-37).

questions.question: True or False: The chapter shows that God uses ordinary people, like Jehu, to accomplish His purposes when they obey Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jehu, a captain’s son, was chosen and empowered by God through the prophet to carry out His judgment (2 Kings 9:1-7, 9:13-14).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness and reconciliation after betrayal. Based on Jehu's actions, what biblical principle would you emphasize?
options: Justice and obedience to God's word must be prioritized
questions.correctAnswer: Justice and obedience to God's word must be prioritized
questions.explanation: Jehu acted decisively to fulfill God's justice against Jezebel’s house, showing that obedience and justice are crucial even amid betrayal (2 Kings 9:7-10, 9:22-27).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jehu was anointed king over Israel by pouring oil on his ______.
questions.correctAnswer: head
questions.explanation: The prophet poured the box of oil on Jehu's head to anoint him king, symbolizing God's appointment (2 Kings 9:3, 9:6).

questions.question: How does the story of Jehu in 2 Kings 9 encourage believers to be faithful witnesses in their daily work?
options: Faithfulness to God’s mission requires courage and integrity
Work is unimportant in spiritual life
Success depends solely on human effort
Avoid difficult tasks to stay safe
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God’s mission requires courage and integrity
questions.explanation: Jehu's determined actions in carrying out God’s judgment demonstrate the need for courage and integrity in fulfilling God’s purposes in all areas (2 Kings 9:14-24, 9:27).

questions.question: What does Jehu’s immediate call to action after being anointed teach about the importance of evangelism and sharing God's messages?
options: Act quickly to proclaim and fulfill God's word
Wait for perfect conditions before acting
questions.correctAnswer: Act quickly to proclaim and fulfill God's word
questions.explanation: Jehu did not hesitate after being anointed but immediately began acting on God's command, showing the importance of urgency in sharing and living out God's word (2 Kings 9:3, 9:14-15).

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 9.

questions.question: Who was anointed king over Israel by the young prophet sent by Elisha?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehu
questions.explanation: The prophet poured oil on Jehu's head and declared him king over Israel as commanded by Elisha (2 Kings 9:6).

questions.question: What was the purpose of anointing Jehu king according to the prophet's words?
options: To smite the house of Ahab and avenge the prophets' blood
questions.correctAnswer: To smite the house of Ahab and avenge the prophets' blood
questions.explanation: The prophet said Jehu was anointed to smite Ahab's house and avenge the blood of the LORD’s servants killed by Jezebel (2 Kings 9:7).

questions.question: What does the prophecy say will happen to Jezebel?
options: Dogs will eat her in Jezreel and none will bury her
She will flee to another country
questions.correctAnswer: Dogs will eat her in Jezreel and none will bury her
questions.explanation: The prophecy foretold that Jezebel's body would be eaten by dogs in Jezreel with no one to bury her (2 Kings 9:10).

questions.question: How did Jehu respond when asked if he came in peace?
options: What hast thou to do with peace? turn thee behind me
questions.correctAnswer: What hast thou to do with peace? turn thee behind me
questions.explanation: Jehu rejected the message of peace, indicating his mission was violent, telling the messenger to turn behind him (2 Kings 9:18).

questions.question: Where did Jehu kill King Joram of Israel?
options: In his chariot at the portion of Naboth the Jezreelite
At the city gate of Ramothgilead
questions.correctAnswer: In his chariot at the portion of Naboth the Jezreelite
questions.explanation: Jehu shot Joram with an arrow between the arms while he was in his chariot at Naboth's vineyard (2 Kings 9:24).

questions.question: What is the significance of casting Joram’s body into Naboth’s field according to the text?
options: It fulfilled the LORD’s curse related to Naboth’s murder
It was an act of dishonor unrelated to prophecy
It was a royal burial custom
questions.correctAnswer: It fulfilled the LORD’s curse related to Naboth’s murder
questions.explanation: Jehu commanded Joram’s body be thrown into Naboth’s field to fulfill God’s word regarding the blood of Naboth and his sons (2 Kings 9:25-26).

questions.question: How did Ahaziah, king of Judah, die according to the chapter?
options: He fled and was struck down at Megiddo
He died in battle against Syria
questions.correctAnswer: He fled and was struck down at Megiddo
questions.explanation: Ahaziah fled after Joram’s death but was pursued and killed at Megiddo (2 Kings 9:27).

questions.question: What was Jezebel’s reaction when she heard Jehu had come to Jezreel?
options: She painted her face, adorned her head, and looked out a window
She prepared a feast for Jehu
questions.correctAnswer: She painted her face, adorned her head, and looked out a window
questions.explanation: Jezebel prepared herself by painting her face and adorning her head as Jehu approached (2 Kings 9:30).

questions.question: What was Jehu's command upon seeing Jezebel at the window, and what was the result?
options: Throw her down; she was thrown down and trodden underfoot
Take her captive; she was imprisoned
questions.correctAnswer: Throw her down; she was thrown down and trodden underfoot
questions.explanation: Jehu ordered Jezebel to be thrown down from the window, resulting in her death and her blood splattering on the wall and horses (2 Kings 9:33).

questions.question: What portion of Jezebel’s body was found when her servants went to bury her?
options: Only the skull, feet, and palms of hands
questions.correctAnswer: Only the skull, feet, and palms of hands
questions.explanation: When they went to bury Jezebel, only the skull, feet, and palms of her hands were found (2 Kings 9:35).

questions.question: According to the text, what did Jehu say about Jezebel after her death?
options: She is a king's daughter and cursed
questions.correctAnswer: She is a king's daughter and cursed
questions.explanation: Jehu commanded her burial while calling her a cursed king's daughter (2 Kings 9:34).

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophet’s word did Jehu cite regarding Jezebel’s fate?
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah the Tishbite
questions.explanation: Jehu said Jezebel's fate was the word of the LORD spoken through Elijah the Tishbite (2 Kings 9:36).

questions.question: What literary device is seen when the chapter describes Jehu’s furious driving and the watchman recognizing it?
questions.correctAnswer: Foreshadowing of Jehu’s violent overthrow
questions.explanation: The watchman’s recognition of Jehu’s furious driving foreshadows the violent coup Jehu is about to execute (2 Kings 9:20).

questions.question: True or False: The anointing of Jehu fulfilled a divine mandate to end the house of Ahab as a judgment for their idolatry and killing of prophets.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The anointing was a divine command to destroy Ahab’s house and avenge the prophets slain by Jezebel, as stated in 2 Kings 9:7-9.

questions.question: True or False: The death of Ahaziah king of Judah occurred before the death of Joram king of Israel in this chapter.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ahaziah fled after Joram was killed and was then struck down at Megiddo (2 Kings 9:24-27).

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the purpose of Elisha instructing the young prophet to anoint Jehu as king over Israel?
options: To overthrow the house of Ahab and avenge the prophets' blood
To restore the temple worship in Israel
To build a new city in Ramothgilead
questions.correctAnswer: To overthrow the house of Ahab and avenge the prophets' blood
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 9:6-7 states God’s command through Elisha to anoint Jehu king in order to smite the house of Ahab and avenge the blood of the prophets and servants of the LORD. This shows God's justice and judgment against sin, consistent with God's holiness and retribution in Scripture (Deuteronomy 32:35, Romans 12:19, Psalm 94:1-2, Hebrews 10:30).

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 9, how does God describe the fate of Jezebel?
options: The dogs shall eat Jezebel in the portion of Jezreel, and there shall be none to bury her
She shall be exalted among the nations
She will reign as queen forever
She will be taken captive to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The dogs shall eat Jezebel in the portion of Jezreel, and there shall be none to bury her
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 9:10 and 9:36-37 describe Jezebel's judgment explicitly as being eaten by dogs with no proper burial. This reflects divine condemnation of wickedness and idolatry, in line with God's justice against evil as seen in Exodus 22:31, Psalm 22:16-18, and Revelation 19:20.

questions.question: What does Jehu’s anointing and immediate action to destroy Ahab’s house reveal about God’s sovereignty and justice?
options: God sovereignly raises instruments to execute His judgment on sin
God allows human kings to rule without interference
God forgives all sin without consequence
God desires peace with all nations regardless of their sin
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly raises instruments to execute His judgment on sin
questions.explanation: Jehu’s anointing (2 Kings 9:6-10) and his swift execution of judgment show God’s sovereign control over history and His righteous judgment, consistent with biblical themes of God raising up and using people for His purposes (Romans 9:17-18, Isaiah 10:5-7, Psalm 75:6-7, Acts 17:26).

questions.question: Why does Jehu reject the messenger’s question, 'Is it peace?' when he approaches Jezreel?
options: Because he is enforcing divine judgment and war, not peace
Because he is unaware of the conflict
Because he wants to negotiate a treaty
Because he seeks to flee from battle
questions.correctAnswer: Because he is enforcing divine judgment and war, not peace
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 9:18, 9:19 show Jehu's response rejecting peace, indicating the divine mandate for judgment upon Ahab’s house. This reflects the biblical theme that God's justice sometimes involves conflict and judgment (Ecclesiastes 3:3, Nahum 1:2, Romans 13:4, Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: What theological truth is demonstrated by Jehu’s fulfillment of the prophecy against Naboth’s blood?
options: God’s justice is sure and avenges innocent blood
God overlooks injustice for political stability
Prophecies can be ignored without consequence
Human rulers act independently of God’s will
questions.correctAnswer: God’s justice is sure and avenges innocent blood
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 9:25-26 shows Jehu fulfilling God’s judgment on Ahab’s house for Naboth’s murder. This illustrates God’s righteous indignation against injustice and His commitment to vindicate the oppressed, consistent with Psalm 9:9-10, Proverbs 21:15, Isaiah 1:17, and Luke 18:7.

questions.question: How does Jehu’s anointing as king relate to the biblical doctrine of divine election and calling?
options: God calls and appoints leaders for His specific purposes
Kingship is based solely on hereditary rights
God has no involvement in political leadership
questions.correctAnswer: God calls and appoints leaders for His specific purposes
questions.explanation: Jehu’s anointing by a prophet under God’s instruction (2 Kings 9:1-6) exemplifies God’s sovereign election and calling, a theme echoed in Scripture about God choosing leaders for His plans (Exodus 3:10, 1 Samuel 16:1-13, Romans 8:28-30, Acts 9:15).

questions.question: What does Jezebel’s final fate symbolize in biblical theology?
options: The ultimate defeat of evil and falsehood
questions.correctAnswer: The ultimate defeat of evil and falsehood
questions.explanation: Jezebel’s death and desecration (2 Kings 9:33-37) symbolize God's triumph over evil, consistent with the biblical portrayal of God’s final victory over wickedness (Genesis 3:15, Revelation 20:10, Psalm 37:10-11, Isaiah 25:8).

questions.question: What does Jehu’s immediate and violent judgment on Joram and Ahaziah reveal about the seriousness of sin in leadership?
options: Sin in leadership brings swift divine judgment
God ignores the sins of kings
questions.correctAnswer: Sin in leadership brings swift divine judgment
questions.explanation: Jehu’s killing of Joram and Ahaziah (2 Kings 9:24-27) demonstrates that leaders are accountable to God for their sins, reflecting the biblical principle that those in authority must uphold righteousness (Romans 13:1-4, 1 Timothy 5:20, Ezekiel 21:25-27, Proverbs 29:2).

questions.question: In what way does 2 Kings 9 demonstrate the attribute of God as a righteous judge?
options: By executing justice on Ahab's house for their sins
By allowing evil to prosper forever
questions.correctAnswer: By executing justice on Ahab's house for their sins
questions.explanation: The execution of judgment on Ahab’s house (2 Kings 9:7-10, 20-26) reveals God’s attribute as a righteous judge who punishes sin, consistent with Deuteronomy 32:4, Psalm 7:11, Romans 2:5-6, and Revelation 15:3-4.

questions.question: What role do prophets play in 2 Kings 9 that reflects their broader biblical function?
options: They are God’s messengers who anoint kings and pronounce judgment
They serve as political advisors only
They perform miracles independent of God’s will
questions.correctAnswer: They are God’s messengers who anoint kings and pronounce judgment
questions.explanation: Elisha sending a prophet to anoint Jehu (2 Kings 9:1-6) shows prophets as God’s appointed spokesmen who enforce divine will, consistent with roles of prophets in Scripture (Isaiah 6:8-10, Jeremiah 1:4-10, Amos 3:7, Hebrews 1:1).

questions.question: How does the fulfillment of Elijah’s prophecy regarding Jezebel in 2 Kings 9 affirm the trustworthiness of God's Word?
options: It confirms that God's prophecies are certain and come to pass
It shows that prophecies can be ignored
It suggests God changes His mind frequently
It indicates that prophecy is symbolic only
questions.correctAnswer: It confirms that God's prophecies are certain and come to pass
questions.explanation: Jehu’s report in 2 Kings 9:36-37 cites Elijah’s prophecy fulfilled exactly, affirming divine faithfulness to His word, consistent with biblical teaching about the reliability of prophecy (Numbers 23:19, Isaiah 55:11, 2 Peter 1:20-21, John 17:17).

questions.question: What does Jehu’s question to Jezebel, 'Who is on my side?' indicate about divine authority and human allegiance?
options: Divine authority calls for decisive human allegiance
Human allegiance is irrelevant to divine plans
Divine authority is passive and indifferent
Allegiance should be to worldly powers
questions.correctAnswer: Divine authority calls for decisive human allegiance
questions.explanation: Jehu’s challenge (2 Kings 9:32) signifies the call for allegiance to God’s appointed king, reflecting the biblical demand for loyalty to God’s authority (Joshua 24:15, Romans 13:1, 1 Samuel 12:14-15, Revelation 3:20).

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 9 illustrate the principle of divine retribution in the history of Israel?
options: God repays the sins of leaders and nations accordingly
God rewards all leaders regardless of their actions
Sin has no consequences in history
Leadership is unrelated to divine judgment
questions.correctAnswer: God repays the sins of leaders and nations accordingly
questions.explanation: The destruction of Ahab’s house and Jezebel (2 Kings 9:7-10, 24-37) exemplifies divine retribution, consistent with biblical teaching that sin brings consequences (Leviticus 26:14-39, Deuteronomy 28, Jeremiah 18:7-10, Galatians 6:7).

questions.question: What does the behavior of Jehu after killing Jezebel (eating and drinking) signify about God's judgment and human response?
options: God’s judgment brings decisive change and restoration of order
Judgment leads to despair and hopelessness
God’s judgment is always accompanied by destruction without restoration
Human response to judgment is irrelevant
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment brings decisive change and restoration of order
questions.explanation: Jehu’s calm eating and drinking after Jezebel’s death (2 Kings 9:34) reflects confidence in God’s justice and the restoration of right order, paralleling biblical narratives where judgment is followed by renewal (Nehemiah 8:10, Ezekiel 36:26-27, Isaiah 61:3, Revelation 22:3).

questions.question: What does the narrative of Jehu’s anointing and actions teach about God’s use of imperfect instruments to accomplish His purposes?
options: God uses flawed humans to fulfill His sovereign will
Only perfect people can be used by God
God’s plans depend on human perfection
God does not intervene in human affairs
questions.correctAnswer: God uses flawed humans to fulfill His sovereign will
questions.explanation: Jehu, though imperfect, is chosen by God to execute judgment (2 Kings 9:1-13), illustrating God’s use of imperfect vessels to accomplish divine goals, consistent with biblical examples like Moses (Exodus 4), Gideon (Judges 6), and Paul (1 Corinthians 1:27-29, 2 Corinthians 12:9).
